natural problem:
The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular}
natural solution: We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real" and extra_charge :: "real * real => bool"
defines "A \<equiv> (6, 4)" and "B \<equiv> (9, 3)" and "C \<equiv> (6, 6)" and "D \<equiv> (11, 4)"
defines "extra_charge pair \<equiv> (let (length, height) = pair in length / height < 1.3 \<or> length / height > 2.5)"
shows  "count [A, B, C, D] extra_charge = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real" and extra_charge :: "real * real => bool"
defines "A \<equiv> (6, 4)" and "B \<equiv> (9, 3)" and "C \<equiv> (6, 6)" and "D \<equiv> (11, 4)"
defines "extra_charge pair \<equiv> (let (length, height) = pair in length / height < 1.3 \<or> length / height > 2.5)"
shows  "count [A, B, C, D] extra_charge = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider four rectangular parcels with the following length and height measurements: Parcel A is 6x4, Parcel B is 9x3, Parcel C is 6x6, and Parcel D is 11x4. An additional fee is applied to any parcel whose ratio of length to height is either less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5. How many of the parcels will incur the additional fee? The answer is 3.

a_1.formal problem:
datatype Envelope = A | B | C | D

fun extra_charge :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"extra_charge A = (6/4 < 1.3 \<or> 6/4 > 2.5)" |
"extra_charge B = (9/3 < 1.3 \<or> 9/3 > 2.5)" |
"extra_charge C = (6/6 < 1.3 \<or> 6/6 > 2.5)" |
"extra_charge D = (11/4 < 1.3 \<or> 11/4 > 2.5)"

theorem
shows  "card {e. extra_charge e} = 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

datatype Envelope = A | B | C | D

fun extra_charge :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"extra_charge A = (6/4 < 1.3 \<or> 6/4 > 2.5)" |
"extra_charge B = (9/3 < 1.3 \<or> 9/3 > 2.5)" |
"extra_charge C = (6/6 < 1.3 \<or> 6/6 > 2.5)" |
"extra_charge D = (11/4 < 1.3 \<or> 11/4 > 2.5)"

theorem
shows  "card {e. extra_charge e} = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Consider four types of envelopes: A, B, C, and D. An envelope incurs an extra charge if its length to width ratio is less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5. The ratios for the envelopes are as follows: 

- Envelope A: 6/4 
- Envelope B: 9/3 
- Envelope C: 6/6 
- Envelope D: 11/4 

How many types of envelopes will incur an extra charge? The final answer is 3.

a_2.formal problem:
datatype Envelope = A | B | C | D

fun length :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"length A = 6" |
"length B = 9" |
"length C = 6" |
"length D = 11"

fun height :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"height A = 4" |
"height B = 3" |
"height C = 6" |
"height D = 4"

definition extra_charge :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"extra_charge e = ((length e / height e) < 1.3 \<or> (length e / height e) > 2.5)"

fun count_extra_charges :: "Envelope list \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"count_extra_charges [] = 0" |
"count_extra_charges (e#es) = (if extra_charge e then 1 else 0) + count_extra_charges es"

theorem
shows  "count_extra_charges [A, B, C, D] = 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

datatype Envelope = A | B | C | D

fun length :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"length A = 6" |
"length B = 9" |
"length C = 6" |
"length D = 11"

fun height :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"height A = 4" |
"height B = 3" |
"height C = 6" |
"height D = 4"

definition extra_charge :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"extra_charge e = ((length e / height e) < 1.3 \<or> (length e / height e) > 2.5)"

fun count_extra_charges :: "Envelope list \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"count_extra_charges [] = 0" |
"count_extra_charges (e#es) = (if extra_charge e then 1 else 0) + count_extra_charges es"

theorem
shows  "count_extra_charges [A, B, C, D] = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are four types of envelopes: A, B, C, and D. The lengths of these envelopes are 6, 9, 6, and 11 respectively. The heights of these envelopes are 4, 3, 6, and 4 respectively. If the ratio of the length to the height of an envelope is less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5, an extra charge is applied. How many envelopes out of A, B, C, and D will incur an extra charge? The final answer is 3.

a_3.formal problem:
datatype Envelope = A | B | C | D

fun length :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"length A = 6" |
"length B = 9" |
"length C = 6" |
"length D = 11"

fun height :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"height A = 4" |
"height B = 3" |
"height C = 6" |
"height D = 4"

theorem
assumes h0 : "\<forall> e. (length e / height e < 1.3) \<or> (length e / height e > 2.5) \<longrightarrow> extra_charge e = 0.11"
shows  "card {e. extra_charge e = 0.11} = 3"

There are four types of envelopes: A, B, C, and D. The dimensions of the envelopes are as follows: 

- Envelope A has a length of 6 and a height of 4.
- Envelope B has a length of 9 and a height of 3.
- Envelope C has a length of 6 and a height of 6.

An extra charge of 0.11 is applied to envelopes where the ratio of length to height is less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5. 

How many types of envelopes have an extra charge of 0.11? The final answer is 3.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "(real * real)"
assumes h0 : "A = (6, 4)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 3)"
and h2 : "C = (6, 6)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 4)"
and h4 : "extra_charge E \<equiv> (fst E / snd E < 1.3) \<or> (fst E / snd E > 2.5)"
shows  "{E. extra_charge E} = {A, B, D}"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "(real * real)"
assumes h0 : "A = (6, 4)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 3)"
and h2 : "C = (6, 6)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 4)"
and h4 : "extra_charge E \<equiv> (fst E / snd E < 1.3) \<or> (fst E / snd E > 2.5)"
shows  "{E. extra_charge E} = {A, B, D}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: We have four pairs of real numbers: A is (6, 4), B is (9, 3), C is (6, 6), and D is (11, 4). An extra charge applies to a pair if the ratio of the first number to the second number is less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5. Which pairs incur an extra charge? The final answer is pairs A, B, and D.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes extra_charge :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> l h. extra_charge l h = ((l / h < 1.3) \<or> (l / h > 2.5))"
shows  "extra_charge 6 4 \<and> extra_charge 9 3 \<and> extra_charge 6 6 \<and> extra_charge 11 4 = 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline

B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem 
fixes extra_charge :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> l h. extra_charge l h = ((l / h < 1.3) \<or> (l / h > 2.5))"
shows  "extra_charge 6 4 \<and> extra_charge 9 3 \<and> extra_charge 6 6 \<and> extra_charge 11 4 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Assuming that an extra charge is applied when the ratio of two values (l and h) is less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5, determine how many of the following pairs trigger the extra charge: (6, 4), (9, 3), (6, 6), and (11, 4). The final answer is 3.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes envelope_A envelope_B envelope_C envelope_D :: "(real * real)" 
assumes h0 : "envelope_A = (6,4)"
and h1 : "envelope_B = (9,3)"
and h2 : "envelope_C = (6,6)"
and h3 : "envelope_D = (11,4)"
and h4 : "extra_charge e = (if fst e / snd e < 1.3 \<or> fst e / snd e > 2.5 then 0.11 else 0)"
shows  "extra_charge envelope_A + extra_charge envelope_B + extra_charge envelope_C + extra_charge envelope_D = 3 * 0.11"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes envelope_A envelope_B envelope_C envelope_D :: "(real * real)" 
assumes h0 : "envelope_A = (6,4)"
and h1 : "envelope_B = (9,3)"
and h2 : "envelope_C = (6,6)"
and h3 : "envelope_D = (11,4)"
and h4 : "extra_charge e = (if fst e / snd e < 1.3 \<or> fst e / snd e > 2.5 then 0.11 else 0)"
shows  "extra_charge envelope_A + extra_charge envelope_B + extra_charge envelope_C + extra_charge envelope_D = 3 * 0.11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
You have four envelopes. The dimensions in inches (width and height) for each are as follows: Envelope A is 6 by 4, Envelope B is 9 by 3, Envelope C is 6 by 6, and Envelope D is 11 by 4.

The post office charges an extra fee of $0.11 for envelopes where the ratio of width to height is less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5. Calculate the total extra charge for these four envelopes. The final answer is $0.33.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "(real \<times> real) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> (l,h). f (l,h) = ((l / h < 1.3) \<or> (l / h > 2.5))"
and h1 : "f (6,4)"
and h2 : "f (9,3)"
and h3 : "f (6,6)"
and h4 : "f (11,4)"
shows  "card {e. e = A \<or> e = B \<or> e = C \<or> e = D \<and> f e} = 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "(real \<times> real) \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> (l,h). f (l,h) = ((l / h < 1.3) \<or> (l / h > 2.5))"
and h1 : "f (6,4)"
and h2 : "f (9,3)"
and h3 : "f (6,6)"
and h4 : "f (11,4)"
shows  "card {e. e = A \<or> e = B \<or> e = C \<or> e = D \<and> f e} = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are four pairs of real numbers (A, B, C, D), which are (6,4), (9,3), (6,6), and (11,4) respectively. A function $f$ is defined such that for each pair, $f$ returns true if the ratio of the first to the second number is either less than 1.3 or greater than 2.5. How many of the pairs make the function $f$ return true? The final answer is 3.

a_9.formal problem:
The given problem is a computation problem rather than a theorem to be proved, so it does not translate directly into an Isabelle theorem. However, we could model the problem situation in Isabelle like so:

datatype Envelope = A | B | C | D

fun length :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"length A = 6" |
"length B = 9" |
"length C = 6" |
"length D = 11"

fun height :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"height A = 4" |
"height B = 3" |
"height C = 6" |
"height D = 4"

definition charge_extra :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"charge_extra e = (length e / height e < 1.3 \<or> length e / height e > 2.5)"

definition count_extra_charge :: "Envelope list \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"count_extra_charge es = length (filter charge_extra es)"

value "count_extra_charge [A, B, C, D]"  (* expected output: 3 *)
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The United States Postal Service charges an extra $\$0.11$ in postage if the length of an envelope, in inches, divided by its height, in inches, is less than $1.3$ or greater than $2.5.$ For how many of these four envelopes must the extra $\$0.11$ in postage be paid? \begin{tabular}[t]{ccc}
Envelope & Length in inches & Height in inches\\\hline
A &6 &4\\
B &9 &3\\
C &6 &6\\
D &11 &4
\end{tabular} The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 We calculate the desired ratio for each envelope: \begin{align} \text{A} &= \frac{6}{4} = 1.5 \\ \text{B} &= \frac{9}{3} = 3 \\ \text{C} &= \frac{6}{6} = 1 \\ \text{D} &= \frac{11}{4} = 2.75 \end{align} $\text B,$ $\text C,$ and $\text D$ are out of range, so the answer is $\boxed{3}.$
 *)

The given problem is a computation problem rather than a theorem to be proved, so it does not translate directly into an Isabelle theorem. However, we could model the problem situation in Isabelle like so:

datatype Envelope = A | B | C | D

fun length :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"length A = 6" |
"length B = 9" |
"length C = 6" |
"length D = 11"

fun height :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> real" where
"height A = 4" |
"height B = 3" |
"height C = 6" |
"height D = 4"

definition charge_extra :: "Envelope \<Rightarrow> bool" where
"charge_extra e = (length e / height e < 1.3 \<or> length e / height e > 2.5)"

definition count_extra_charge :: "Envelope list \<Rightarrow> nat" where
"count_extra_charge es = length (filter charge_extra es)"

value "count_extra_charge [A, B, C, D]"  (* expected output: 3 *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
There are four types of envelopes: A, B, C, and D. The length and height (in some unit) of each envelope are as follows:
- Envelope A: length = 6, height = 4
- Envelope B: length = 9, height = 3
- Envelope C: length = 6, height = 6
- Envelope D: length = 11, height = 4

An extra charge is applied if the ratio of length to height is less than 1.3 or more than 2.5. 

Given a list of envelopes [A, B, C, D], how many envelopes will require an extra charge? The expected answer is 3.
